content: The "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" was established to address the significant increase in tuition at public colleges and universities, which outpaced the rise in household income and consumer goods costs. Concerns about college affordability were at a 30-year high, making college education one of the most expensive investments for American families. The "National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education" is established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" to address the rising tuition costs at public colleges and universities. The Commission established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. Each member must have expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The Commission established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. The members shall elect a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with a majority constituting a quorum for business transactions. Appointments must be made within 30 days, with provisions for appointments if not made within the specified timeframe. The Commission established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. Appointments may be made for officers such as the Speaker of the House, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Minority Leader of the Senate. Each member of the Commission is entitled to one vote, with vacancies not affecting its operations. The Commission, consisting of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education, operates with each member having one vote. Vacancies do not impact its powers, and members do not receive additional pay. The initial meeting must occur within 40 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission will study and make recommendations on the increase in tuition, methods to reduce tuition, trends in administrative costs, faculty workload and remuneration, faculty-to-student ratios, and tenure practices. The Commission will study trends in construction and renovation of facilities, modernization for new technologies, financial aid impact on tuition increases, and laws affecting tuition. The Commission will analyze the impact of financial aid, laws, and regulations on tuition increases, and recommend ways to reduce mandates. They will also establish a mechanism for timely data distribution on tuition trends and other costs. Additionally, the Commission will assess the contribution of student financial aid programs to rising tuition and address other relevant topics. A final report will be submitted to the President and Congress within 120 days of the first meeting. The Commission will submit a report within 120 days of their first meeting, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action. Recommendations require a majority vote from Commission members present and voting. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission, under Section 5, has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out its duties. The Commission, under Section 5, can request information from federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. Federal agencies must provide facilities, services, and personnel to the Commission upon request by the Chairperson. The Commission is also authorized to use the United States mails. The Commission, under Section 5, can request information from federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. It may use the United States mails and enter into contracts for research purposes. The Chairperson has the power to appoint staff members. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an Executive Director and additional staff, set their compensation rates, without being bound by certain provisions of the United States Code. The Commission's expenses are authorized up to $650,000 and funds remain available until expended or one year after the Commission's termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report.
